title: Zeus
description: The king of the gods, ruler of Mount Olympus, and god of the sky and thunder.
quote: Zeus, the cloud-gatherer, rules with justice. — Homer, *The Iliad*

title: Athena
description: The goddess of wisdom, warfare, and crafts. She is known for her strategic skill in battle.
quote: Through war, wisdom conquers brute force. — Plato, referencing Athena

title: Heracles
description: A legendary hero known for his incredible strength and the completion of the Twelve Labors.
quote: No man is so brave that he does not fear death. — Euripides, referencing Heracles

title: Cerberus
description: The three-headed dog that guards the entrance to the underworld.
quote: Even the gates of Hades are guarded by Cerberus. — Virgil, *Aeneid*

title: Mount Olympus
description: The home of the Greek gods, located high above the clouds.
quote: On Olympus, gods dwell among the stars. — Hesiod, *Theogony*

title: Thor
description: The god of thunder and protector of Asgard, wielding the mighty hammer Mjölnir.
quote: Thor's hammer protects the realms from chaos. — Snorri Sturluson, *Prose Edda*

title: Loki
description: The trickster god, known for his cunning and mischief.
quote: Loki's lies weave threads of fate. — Snorri Sturluson, *Prose Edda*

title: Odin
description: The Allfather of Norse mythology, god of war, wisdom, and death.
quote: For wisdom, Odin sacrificed his eye. — Snorri Sturluson, *Prose Edda*

title: Fenrir
description: The giant wolf destined to bring chaos during Ragnarök.
quote: Fenrir's fangs shall pierce the heavens. — Völuspá, *Poetic Edda*

title: Asgard
description: The realm of the gods in Norse mythology, connected to Midgard by the Bifröst bridge.
quote: Asgard stands eternal, until the end of days. — Snorri Sturluson, *Prose Edda*

title: Dagda
description: The father of all gods in Celtic mythology, associated with life, death, and rebirth.
quote: Dagda holds the cauldron of plenty. — Irish Mythology, *The Book of Invasions*

title: Cú Chulainn
description: A legendary hero of Irish mythology, known for his unmatched strength and bravery.
quote: Cú Chulainn stood alone against armies. — Táin Bó Cúailnge (*The Cattle Raid of Cooley*)

title: Banshee
description: A female spirit in Irish folklore whose wail foretells death.
quote: The banshee's cry echoes through the night. — Irish Folklore

title: Stonehenge
description: A mysterious prehistoric monument in England, steeped in Celtic legend.
quote: Stonehenge whispers secrets of the ancients. — Geoffrey of Monmouth, *Historia Regum Britanniae*

title: Excalibur
description: The legendary sword of King Arthur, symbolizing divine kingship and power.
quote: From the stone, Excalibur was drawn by destiny. — Thomas Malory, *Le Morte d'Arthur*

title: Poseidon
description: The god of the sea, earthquakes, and horses. He wields the trident as his symbol of power.
quote: The sea obeys Poseidon's will. — Homer, *The Odyssey*

title: Apollo
description: The god of the sun, music, prophecy, and healing.
quote: Apollo's arrows bring both death and cure. — Ovid, *Metamorphoses*

title: Ares
description: The god of war, known for his fierce and brutal nature.
quote: Ares revels in the chaos of battle. — Hesiod, *Theogony*

title: Medusa
description: A monstrous creature with snakes for hair whose gaze turns people to stone.
quote: Medusa's gaze froze heroes in their tracks. — Ovid, *Metamorphoses*

title: Delphi
description: The sacred site of the Oracle of Delphi, where prophecies were delivered in Apollo's name.
quote: Know thyself, inscribed at Delphi. — Ancient Greek Maxim

title: Freyja
description: The goddess of love, beauty, and fertility, as well as a master of magic.
quote: Freyja weaves spells and rides her chariot drawn by cats. — Snorri Sturluson, *Prose Edda*

title: Heimdall
description: The guardian of the Bifröst bridge, watching over Asgard.
quote: Heimdall sees all, even the smallest blade of grass. — Völuspá, *Poetic Edda*

title: Sigurd
description: A legendary hero who slew the dragon Fafnir and gained its treasure.
quote: Sigurd's courage was unmatched, even among gods. — Völsunga Saga

title: Jormungandr
description: The world serpent destined to fight Thor during Ragnarök.
quote: Thor and Jormungandr shall meet in their final battle. — Völuspá, *Poetic Edda*

title: Valhalla
description: The majestic hall where fallen warriors are taken by the Valkyries to feast with Odin.
quote: Valhalla awaits the bravest of warriors. — Snorri Sturluson, *Prose Edda*

title: Lugh
description: The master of all skills, associated with light and craftsmanship.
quote: Lugh crafted weapons that could pierce any armor. — Irish Mythology

title: Morrigan
description: The goddess of war and fate, often appearing as a crow.
quote: Morrigan foretells victory or doom on the battlefield. — Táin Bó Cúailnge

title: Fionn Mac Cumhaill
description: A legendary hero and leader of the Fianna, known for his wisdom and bravery.
quote: Fionn's wisdom came from tasting the Salmon of Knowledge. — Irish Folklore

title: Dullahan
description: A headless rider who carries his own severed head and foretells death.
quote: The Dullahan rides when death is near. — Irish Folklore

title: Newgrange
description: An ancient passage tomb in Ireland, aligned with the winter solstice sunrise.
quote: Newgrange holds the secrets of the ancients. — Irish Archaeological Studies

title: Gungnir
description: Odin's magical spear, said to never miss its mark.
quote: Gungnir strikes true, guided by Odin's hand. — Snorri Sturluson, *Prose Edda*

title: Brigid
description: The goddess of poetry, healing, and smithcraft.
quote: Brigid's flame burns bright with inspiration. — Irish Mythology

title: Hela
description: The ruler of Helheim, the realm of the dead in Norse mythology.
quote: Hela guards the gates of Helheim. — Snorri Sturluson, *Prose Edda*

title: Tyr
description: The god of law and heroic glory, known for sacrificing his hand to bind Fenrir.
quote: Tyr's sacrifice ensured justice for all. — Snorri Sturluson, *Prose Edda*

title: Connla's Well
description: A mythical well in Celtic legend, said to be the source of all wisdom.
quote: Connla's Well grants knowledge to those who seek it. — Irish Mythology
